The entrance door and right side lower support beam of the enclosure housing 2 yellow headed amazon parrots are badly
rusted. There are holes in the rusted metal large enought to trap a birds legs or head . These areas have sharp points that
could easily injure a bird. Enclosures for all birds must be structurally strong and kept in good repair . CORRECT BY :

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The enrichment plan approved by the attending veterinarian includes a list of enrichment items to be given to the birds,
variety in diet to be provided and discusses social housing needs of birds. There is no documentation that the enrichment
plan has every been followed. At time of the inspection, the enclosures for all the parrot species had few enrichment items
other than wooden perches in the enclosures. The section describing enrichment for the monk parakeet states this is a
very social species that needs other birds. The one monk parakeet is housed in an enclosure inside a building with no
other avian species within sight or sound. He has been diagnosed by the attending veterinarian as a chronic feather
plucker and the AV stated to the inspector that it is moist likely due to stress of social isolation . The Blue and Gold
Macaw is housed alone and also has no visual contact with other avian species . There is no indication that the dietary
enrichment is being given . The food provided to the monk parakeet was 90 % sunflower seeds with one slice of apple
wedged in the cage bars . The enrichment plan as approved by the attending veterinarian must be folllowed and
documented to promote the psychological well being of the birds . CORRECT BY : 1/14/2024

Both the program of veterinary care and enrichment plan as approved by the attending veterinarian state an all seed diet
should not be fed. At time of the inspection, the monk parakeets food appeared to be 90 % sunflower with a view pieces
of corn mixed with the sunflower seed . There was one apple slice wedged between the cage bars. The manager stated
that this not a commerical parrot seed mix but was one made up by facility employees . The monk parakeet has a chronic
feather plucking condition which may be made worse by a poor diet lacking in vitamins. The homemade seed mixture may
not contain proper vitamin levels and a diet high in sunflower seeds is known to be high in fat which can result in health
problems for the birds. The diet for birds must be appropriate for the species, size, age, and condition of the bird. The
food must be wholesome, palatable to the birds, and free of contamination. It must be of sufficient quantity and nutritive
value to maintain a healthy condition and weight range of the bird and to meet its normal daily nutritional requirements.
CORRECT BY : 12/18/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the manager.
